title: Doesn't the mere fact that the universe, matter, time, reality, or anything that irrefutably exists mean that some'thing' HAD to have created it? Even the singularity must've come from something else, right? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Doesn't the mere fact that the universe, matter, time, reality, or anything that irrefutably exists mean that some"thing" HAD to have created it? A: No. There are quite a lot of models that work quite fine without something creating them. The problem is that we can’t prove which one of them, if any, is right. The idea that some “thing” “had to create it” is anthropomorphising the unknown, to make it into a person. It’s actually a sign that we still have a brain focused on telling stories, rather than understanding physics and mathematics. Terry Pratchett once argued that we should not call ourselves Homo sapiens, the wise man; but rather Pan narrans, the storytelling ape. Q: Even the singularity must've come from something else, right? A: To answer that, we must first learn a few things about singularities. Singularities are problem points in mathematics. It’s often undefined or tends towards infinity, or both. 1/0 is a singularity.In physics, singularities often means that there is something fishy with your theory.So where does the singularity come from? In the late 1920s, Georges Lemaître (physicist, astronomer, mathematician, and Jesuit priest) played around with Einstein’s General Relativity. Like Alexander Friedmann before him, he figured out that General Relativity predicted that the universe could not be static, which was the paradigm of the time. Instead, Lemaître showed that given the field equations of General Relativity the universe must have had the volume zero at some point in the past. That would also lead to infinite density. It’s a typical singularity in mathematics, and thus a problem point. So when Lemaître presented his idea to the scientific world, including Einstein, it was not well received for three reasons: it was against the paradigm of the time, there was a singularity in it, and it sounded suspiciously much like creation. Not that long after, Edwin Hubble discovered that galaxies were rushing apart. That had the effect that the scientific community started to accept this new paradigm, and that Einstein apologised to Lemaître. With the discovery of the cosmic microwave background radiation in 1964, the case was basically closed. Except for the singularity, which still remains a problem point. It’s not the only one in physics: black holes are another, and there used to be one called the “UV catastrophe”. The problem with the UV catastrophe is that classical blackbody theory didn’t work, and would lead to all matter instantaneously radiating all their energy to near absolute zero and mostly in the ultraviolet range. The solution to that problem was in the then fledgling idea of quantum mechanics: that energy would radiate in form of discrete packets called quanta. We call these particular quanta of electromagnetic energy “photons” today. That solved the UV catastrophe, removed the problem point/singularity, and everyone could breathe easily. The same probably is the case of the Big Bang: the singularity at the beginning remains a problem point, but currently there is not a solution to it. Until we have a solution, we cannot figure out anything about the singularity or even if there actually was a real “everything divided by zero” point in the history of the universe. Since Lemaître toyed with Einstein’s General Relativity, we have had great advances in quantum mechanics. It allows us for instance to make computers that work, like the one you are reading this text on. Just like the UV catastrophe was solved by quantising electromagnetism, perhaps the solution to the singularity lies in quantising gravity of General Relativity. The problem is that we don’t have a theory on quantum gravity. Until we do, we can’t know what happened at the earliest moments of the universe. We can’t even tell if there actually was a singularity. We have a few ideas of what happened before, including that our big bang is the other side of a black hole in a previous universe; that our universe came from a collapse of a previous universe; that there is an eternal inflaton field in which our universe is a slowly-expanding stable (from our point of view) bubble; and my personal favourite, that you can regard gravity as negative energy potential and if you sum up all matter and energy and gravity, you get the sum zero. In the last idea, the zero-energy universe, the universe could not only come from nothing, but would actually still be nothing, only unevenly distributed. All of these models, and more, works fine with physics as we know it, and does not require some “thing” that “created” it. In each of these models, it just happened. The problem is that we just can’t test those models, because we lack a way to go around the problem point that comes from General Relativity.

Well, yes and no. We do not live in a strictly “cause & effect” universe. Much of the time, from our extremely limited perspective, it seems that way, and so we tend to assume that it is that way, a predetermined, deterministic, mechanistic kind of a universe where everything had a cause, everything is predictable, and you can backwards engineer everything that happens, in principle, to see what caused it to happen. But we live in a relativistic, quantum, chaotic, complex universe, and it is especially quantum. That means that things are not predetermined and are probabilistic rather than predictable. Chaos Theory also has a role to play in unpredictability, since it has been found to extend to the quantum level. The quantum butterfly effect, if you will. So the universe does not have to be caused in a Newtonian, classic sense. The singularity didn’t have to come from anything, especially since it seems to have “existed” outside of space, time and the laws of physics, which isn’t even existence the way that we define and experience it. But since we do live in a universe with certain characteristics, we can look at those to see if they suggest a “something” that might be behind it all. And there are several things that do offer that suggestion: Big Bang/Inflation itself, everything coming from nothing in a tiny fraction of a second (I put inflation in there even though it is increasingly being challenged), fine-tuning (all of the laws of physics lining up just so in a phenomenal way, observer-dependency (gotta have an observer in a quantum universe), and an interactional/relational universe where everything we think is something is actually nothing but physical interactions acting persistently like there is something. So, truth is, everything didn’t come from nothing. Nothing came from nothing, but the nothing that is here acts like something persistently enough to fool us. Those would be the clues that There is Something Going On Out There That Might Be a Lot Like God, only not the silly little gods that atheists like to disparage and humans like to worship, by and large. A really respectable God who is outside of time, space and the laws of physics, who observed it all into being and ordered it in such a way, for some bizarre reason, to produce intelligent sentient observers. You and me and all of the people who are going to write nasty comments about this. 1–2–3 go.

Astrophysicists have no idea. Or, rather, our most creative ideas have little or no grounding in experimental science. In response, some religious people assert, with a tinge of righteousness, that something must have started it all: a force greater than all others, a source from which everything issues. A prime mover. In the mind of such a person, that something is, of course, God. But what if the universe was always there, in a state or condition we have yet to identify—a multiverse, for instance, that continually births universes? Or what if the universe just popped into existence from nothing? Or what if everything we know and love were just a computer simulation rendered for entertainment by a superintelligent alien species? These philosophically fun ideas usually satisfy nobody. Nonetheless, they remind us that ignorance is the natural state of mind for a research scientist. People who believe they are ignorant of nothing have neither looked for, nor stumbled upon, the boundary between what is known and unknown in the universe. What we do know, and what we can assert without further hesitation, is that the universe had a beginning. The universe continues to evolve. And yes, every one of our body’s atoms is traceable to the big bang and to the thermonuclear furnaces within high-mass stars that exploded more than five billion years ago. We are stardust brought to life, then empowered by the universe to figure itself out—and we have only just begun.

There are only three possibilities: The universe is eternal and uncaused;The universe was caused; its cause was caused; and so on in an infinite regression; orSome eternal, uncaused mechanism caused the universe.Option 1 contradicts all of our observations of the universe, which indicate that the universe began about 14 billion years ago. See Big Bang - Wikipedia; Option 2 has some logical problems, in that an infinitely regressing sequence of causes ought to exist for some reason, a meta-cause if you will. But the meta-cause itself cannot be the result of an infinite regression; and Option 3 indicates some sort of thing which exists outside of our universe of matter, energy, time an space, and is itself uncaused. Though one might call this thing a transcendent creator, such terminology would not imply a sentient being, nor a designer. See Stephen Sibbald's post in Physics and Metaphysics This logic does not show theism to be true, but it does show materialism to be false.

This remains one of the most enduring arguments for the existence of God, because people seem to have a really hard time understanding it. We know there was a Big Bang. We know a surprising amount about the state of the universe just after that point. But we don’t know anything about what caused it, or what came before. There is no data. The idea that something started the universe is compelling. The danger here is that you call this something the First Cause or the Prime Mover and then it ends up being called God (which sounds reasonable…) but then it gets conflated with the Christian God and all the mythology that comes with it. I’d rather call the start of the universe something like Fred. Nobody would worship a Fred. But here’s the problem. If there was something that started the universe off, where did that something come from? You’ve essentially got three options. The something was always there (eternal).The something was created by something else.There was no something - the universe came from nothing.In the first case, you’ve got another problem. Eternal things don’t change. They can’t. If something changes, it isn’t there any more - a new thing is there instead. And for our universe to be created means something changed - our eternal force went from being force alone to force + universe. (Or, to put it in simpler terms, why would Fred spend an eternity sitting around doing nothing and then one day decide to make a universe? What triggered that decision? And why did he wait?) In the second case, you’ve got a recursion problem. If Fred was created by another force (let’s call it Wilma), where did Wilma come from? Oh, Betty made Wilma. So who made Betty? And so on… now you have an infinite regress. In the third case, you’ve got the same problem as the first but without the eternal force. Rather than God randomly deciding to make a universe for no reason, the universe just happens for no reason. (This is actually a better explanation than God making a sudden decision - it’s fundamentally the same, but simpler, as God isn’t involved - but it still has the same central issue.) Some physicists have a simple explanation for all this, though it isn’t very satisfying. They suggest that there is no “before”. Time started with the Big Bang. Nothing caused it, because there was no time before it TO cause it. Then there’s the idea of a cyclical universe - the Big Bang was the result of a Big Crunch, when the previous universe died and collapsed back into a singularity. One day ours will do the same, and a new universe will be born. This is my favourite, though there’s still absolutely no evidence to support it over any other idea. In summary - we don’t know, and don’t believe anyone who claims they do.

Your question is a ‘human’ question - and we are but a tiny part of the bigger picture. Our thinking based at best on consistency of events and their consequences - this being what is called ‘science’. We’ve worked out that the moon is not made of cheese and realised the Earth is a disc but what gives us the confidence that we can answer questions about creation itself. As the biologist J B Haldane states - ‘The universe is not only stranger than we think - it is stranger than we CAN think’. The answer is therefore - not yet within our grasp - but neither can we assert that ‘knowledge’ does not hold the answer.

The tree in my garden exists, but no ‘thing’ created it. It came into being through the operation of natural processes on a seed, which in turn came into being through the operation of natural processes on a previous tree. We know that many of the objects we encounter every day arose through natural processes, and we have no reason to think otherwise for the extraterrestrial objects that make up the rest of the universe. The fact that some entity exists doesn’t mean it was ‘created’. There are plenty of other ways of coming into being.
